Hi all -

>The order-independent method of activation can utilize a kind 
>of "delay chain memory" while in-order activation cannot...
 >I forget who it was, but a couple years ago
>someone sent me an example where they forgot to enable recurrence in 
>NEAT

This was me, and the problem was my shape recogniser. This was an 
early use of the "roving eye" technique. The network could see a small 
window on the overall shape. For each test, the network was reset, and 
over several timesteps (each an evaluation of the network) had to 
issue commands to move the eye around the shape before finally issuing 
a command saying that it had made its decision.

Since several evaluations were required to solve the problem, the 
network had to evolve some kind of memory. In my first run, I was 
presented after a couple of days with a 100% successful network, which 
seemed rather gangly. Ken kindly drew out a tidied-up version of the 
network, which revealed long strings of nodes connected end-to-end. As 
he was pondering their purpose, I suddenly noticed an error in the 
configuration which meant recurrence had been turned off. The "delay 
lines" (as Ken called them at the time) were providing a rudimentary 
memory for the network during each tests.

The way it worked was, each evaluation, the contents of each node in 
the chain was passing one link further down it. So, the input to a 
delay line of five nodes would appear at the other end after five 
timesteps.

It's surprising that this could take the place of recurrent 
connections, and indeed probably only works in limited circumstances, 
but it did nonetheless solve the problem.

I did try the experiment again with recurrence turned on. Again, it 
finished with a 100% successful network, but it was much simpler than 
the delay line version!

--Darren
